channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Coronavirus Live Updates: White House and Congress Reach $2 Trillion Stimulus Deal
item.description: The legislation, which will send direct payments and jobless benefits to individuals, is the biggest economic stimulus package in modern American history.

item.title: Stock Markets in Asia Continue Global Surge: Live Updates
item.description: Live updates on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
item.media:description: Mitch McConnell, the Senate majority leader, in Washington on Tuesday.

item.title: Slow Response to the Coronavirus Measured in Lost Opportunity
item.description: If the administration had reacted to the ventilator shortage in February, a private sector effort starting now might have made lifesaving equipment in mid- to late April. Now it is unlikely to be before June.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Stephanie Keith for The New York Times
item.media:description: The federal government supplied 400 ventilators to New York, which now accounts for more than 25,000 cases of the coronavirus.

item.title: What I Learned When My Husband Got Sick With Coronavirus
item.description: Our world became one of isolation, round-the-clock care, panic and uncertainty — even as society carried on around us with all too few changes.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Lustig

item.title: Free Access to Coronavirus Coverage
item.description: The Times is providing free access to our most important updates and guidance on the global coronavirus crisis.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Coronavirus in N.Y.: ‘Astronomical’ Surge Leads to Quarantine Warning
item.description: The White House advised people who have passed through or left New York City that they should place themselves in a 14-day quarantine.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer and Brian M. Rosenthal
item.media:credit: Stephanie Keith for The New York Times
item.media:description: New York is projected to need up to 140,000 hospital beds when only about 53,000 are now available for use, the governor said.

item.title: How Andrew Cuomo, New York Governor, Became the Politician of the Moment
item.description: With his coronavirus briefings, Gov. Andrew Cuomo has emerged as an authoritative voice in the crisis.
item.dc:creator: Jesse McKinley and Shane Goldmacher

item.title: Subway Service Is Cut by a Quarter Because of Coronavirus
item.description: A staggering loss of ridership hits the subway system, and 52 M.T.A. workers are infected with the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum
item.media:credit: Stephanie Keith for The New York Times
item.media:description: Subway stations are nearly deserted, with ridership down 87 percent because of the coronavirus.

item.title: Coronavirus Has Hospitals in Desperate Need of Equipment. These Innovators Are Racing to Help.
item.description: Health care workers are facing a serious shortage of critical equipment needed to treat the coronavirus. We spoke to the makers who are building innovative protective gear and ventilators for them.
item.dc:creator: Haley Willis, Robin Stein, Natalie Reneau and Drew Jordan

item.title: A Medical Class ‘Minted by the Pandemic’
item.description: Across the nation, medical students are graduating directly into the path of an epic health crisis.
item.dc:creator: Emma Goldberg
item.media:credit: Stephen Speranza for The New York Times
item.media:description: David Edelman, a fifth-year medical student at Columbia University, helped establish the Covid-19 Student Service Corps to support healthcare providers. “There’s so much to be done,” he said.

item.title: Some Doctors Stockpile Trial Coronavirus Drugs for Themselves, States Say
item.description: The stockpiling has become so worrisome that pharmacy boards in many states have issued emergency restrictions on how the drugs can be dispensed.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Gabler
item.media:credit: Ramin Rahimian for The New York Times
item.media:description: A handful of state pharmacy boards have issued emergency restrictions on how the drugs can be dispensed.

item.title: Coronavirus in India: Modi Orders Total Lockdown of 21 Days
item.description: With four hours’ notice, India’s prime minister announced that no one could leave their homes for 21 days — the most severe step taken anywhere in the war against the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Kai Schultz
item.media:description: A family watching Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Tuesday announcing a total lockdown across India to contain the coronavirus outbreak.

item.title: Britain Locks Down to Stem the Coronavirus. More or Less.
item.description: A day of confusion and contradictory images as Britons struggled to adapt to the new rules, and sometimes just understand them.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: A few shops remained open in an otherwise empty Borough Market near the London Bridge, on Tuesday.

item.title: Coronavirus in Europe: Thousands of Health Workers Out of Action
item.description: The thinning ranks of doctors and nurses, particularly in Spain, are hampering the ability to fight the epidemic, straining hospitals and raising fears that health workers are spreading the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Raphael Minder and Elian Peltier
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: Healthcare workers outside of a hospital in Barcelona, Spain, on Tuesday.

item.title: Facebook Is ‘Just Trying to Keep the Lights On’ as Traffic Soars in Pandemic
item.description: The social network is straining to deal with skyrocketing usage as its 45,000 employees work from home for the first time.
item.dc:creator: Mike Isaac and Sheera Frenkel
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.media:description: Facebook’s 45,000 employees have been asked to work at home during the pandemic, emptying the offices.

item.title: Coronavirus Spurs a Wave of Suspect Websites Looking to Cash In
item.description: Hundreds of e-commerce sites are popping up daily to sell virus-fighting products. Many are being shut down for making exaggerated claims or selling phantom products.
item.dc:creator: Michael H. Keller and Taylor Lorenz
item.media:description: Shopify has registered nearly 500 new e-commerce sites over the past two months with names that include “corona” or “covid.”

item.title: Drivers Say Uber and Lyft Are Blocking Unemployment Pay
item.description: States like New York and California have made gig workers eligible for jobless benefits and sick days. But the companies have resisted complying.
item.dc:creator: Noam Scheiber
item.media:credit: Jessica Pons for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jerome Gage, a Lyft driver in Los Angeles who has lost most of his business, faces difficulty collecting unemployment benefits.

item.title: The Complicated Calculus of Helping Neighbors During a Pandemic
item.description: In the coronavirus crisis, kind gestures like picking up groceries could carry great risk.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal
item.media:credit: Laylah Amatullah Barrayn for The New York Times
item.media:description: Clark Hamel, 24, is staying inside his fourth-floor apartment in Brooklyn because he is immunocompromised.

item.title: Terrence McNally, Tony-Winning Playwright of Gay Life, Dies at 81
item.description: Mr. McNally, who died of coronavirus complications, introduced audiences to characters and situations that most mainstream theater had previously shunted into comic asides.
item.dc:creator: Jesse Green and Neil Genzlinger
item.category: Frankie and Johnny in the Clair de Lune (Play)
item.media:credit: Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times
item.media:description: The playwright Terrence McNally in 2014. His career, which began on Broadway in 1963, continued without much interruption through last year.

item.title: 3 of the Busiest National Parks Close Amid Coronavirus Outbreak
item.description: Yellowstone, Grand Teton and the Great Smoky Mountains national parks cited concerns about social distancing.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.media:description: A tourist taking photographs of Castle Geyser at Yellowstone National Park in 2018.

item.title: Coronavirus, Olympics, Canned Tomatoes: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: Remy Tumin and Hiroko Masuike

item.title: Why the American Approach Is Failing
item.description: “Shelter in place” orders and the closing of businesses are a reaction to the failure to act earlier to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Times Square in New York on Thursday.

item.title: From the Archives: Robert Caro on How He Does It
item.description: The acclaimed biographer of Lyndon Johnson and Robert Moses talks about “Working: Researching, Interviewing, Writing.”

item.title: Sign Up: ‘Coronavirus Briefing’
item.description: An informed guide to the global outbreak.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Coronavirus Is Advancing. All Americans Need to Shelter in Place.
item.description: The worst of the pandemic is yet to come. Listen to the medical experts. It’s time for a national lockdown.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times

item.title: 7 Medical Leaders to Politicians: Save Lives, Not Wall Street
item.description: Don’t open businesses and schools. The economy won’t recover until this pandemic ends.
item.dc:creator: J. Larry Jameson
item.media:credit: Jeenah Moon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hudson Street in Greenwich Village, normally bustling.

item.title: I Followed the U.K.’s Advice. Did I Spread Coronavirus?
item.description: The symptoms are not as straightforward as Boris Johnson makes them seem.
item.dc:creator: Abigail Tarttelin
item.media:description: London’s Westminster Bridge on Tuesday.

item.title: Trump to New York: Drop Dead
item.description: Untold thousands will likely die, absent federal intervention. And it needs to happen this instant. Why won’t the president help?
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Senior

item.title: To Prevent a Coronavirus Depression, Will Trump Trade Away Lives?
item.description: Will he, given his obsession with the economy?
item.dc:creator: Frank Bruni
item.media:description: President Trump on his way to the White House briefing room on Monday.

item.title: Finding the ‘Common Good’ in a Pandemic
item.description: The Harvard political philosopher Michael Sandel offers his take.
item.dc:creator: Thomas L. Friedman
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: Health care workers in Spain responding to people applauding for them from nearby homes.

item.title: I’m on the Front Lines. I Have No Plan for This.
item.description: We’re not allowing visitors in the I.C.U. My patients will suffer in solitary confinement.
item.dc:creator: Daniela J. Lamas
item.media:credit: Ron Chapple/The Image Bank, via Getty Images Plus

item.title: Trump Doesn’t Have the Attention Span to Fight Coronavirus
item.description: He already seems to be losing interest. Look elsewhere for hope.
item.dc:creator: Gail Collins and Bret Stephens

item.title: Will Our Most Important Industry Survive the Coronavirus?
item.description: Better than you might think. Governments need Big Tech now more than ever.
item.dc:creator: Kara Swisher
item.media:description: As more consumers turn to online delivery and entertainment services, companies like Amazon will benefit.

item.title: Coronavirus Advice from a Grocery Store Worker
item.description: Be kind. Don’t let the weight of your grief and anger fall on our shoulders.
item.dc:creator: Dylan Morrison

item.title: After Coronavirus, Will We Have an America Without Restaurants?
item.description: If businesses like ours don’t get help from Washington, more than 10 million Americans could lose their jobs.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Carmellini, Tom Colicchio, Danny Meyer, Missy Robbins, Marcus Samuelsson and Adam Saper
item.media:description: The Daily Provisions cafe on the Upper West Side, a Danny Meyer restaurant.

item.title: What to Watch, Read and Listen To During Your Coronavirus Self-Quarantine
item.description: You’re staying home and you need a distraction. We’re updating this recommendation list every weekday.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: From left, “The Good Place,” “Bluey” and “Knives Out” are among our recommendations for what to watch.

item.title: Livestreaming the Seattle Symphony Became a Source of Connection in Dark Times
item.description: The live performance wasn’t really live, but it felt like being there all the same.
item.dc:creator: Brooke Jarvis

item.title: Great Leadership in a Time of Crisis
item.description: Books from the past show us how John Kennedy, Franklin Roosevelt and Winston Churchill confronted the crises they faced.
item.dc:creator: Jon Meacham
item.category: The Coming of the New Deal (Book)
item.media:credit: Ralph Crane/The LIFE Picture Collection, via Getty Images
item.media:description: People watch as John Kennedy announces a blockade of Cuba, Oct. 22, 1962.

item.title: Bernie Sanders Plans to Participate in Next Debate, Campaign Says
item.description: It was the strongest sign yet that he plans to keep competing against Joe Biden in the Democratic presidential primary.
item.dc:creator: Sydney Ember and Reid J. Epstein
item.media:description: Senator Bernie Sanders at the debate in Washington this month. The Democratic National Committee has said that there would be a debate in April, but one has not been scheduled.

item.title: Texas Tries to Balance Local Control With the Threat of a Global Pandemic
item.description: Texas is the largest state that has not issued a statewide stay-at-home order. With many regions untouched by the coronavirus, Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick wants the economy moving again.
item.dc:creator: Manny Fernandez and David Montgomery
item.media:description: Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick of Texas, center, with President Trump and Attorney General Ken Paxton of Texas, in November.

item.title: Spring Breaker Who Said, 'If I Get Corona, I Get Corona,' Apologizes
item.description: A beachgoer whose defiance of social distancing guidelines drew widespread attention said that he had not been “aware of the severity of my actions and comments.”
item.dc:creator: Aimee Ortiz
item.media:credit: Saul Martinez for The New York Times
item.media:description: College students at a bar in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., on March 11.

item.title: Jeremy Marre, Documentarian of World Music, Is Dead at 76
item.description: With a minimal camera and sound crew, Mr. Marre traveled the world to film music and musicians on home turf that was often gritty and unglamorous.
item.dc:creator: Jon Pareles

item.title: Greta Thunberg Says It’s ‘Extremely Likely’ That She Had Coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.media:description: Greta Thunberg at a meeting of the European Council in Brussels on March 5.

item.title: Women Should be Eligible for US Military Draft
item.description: A commission appointed by Congress will recommend that expanding selective service registration to women is a “necessary and fair step.”
item.dc:creator: Sarah Mervosh and John Ismay
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Melissa Golden for The New York Times
item.media:description: Army cadets at a training exercise in Columbus, Ga.

item.title: 2020 Primary and Election: Has the Coronavirus Postponed It All?
item.description: Primary elections are being pushed back. The Olympics are officially in 2021. The election-year calendar seemed set in stone and now it is up in the air.
item.dc:creator: Matt Flegenheimer
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Aaron Sellers cleaned a voting machine in Columbus, Ohio, in preparation for a primary that ended up being postponed because of the coronavirus.

item.title: Golf Rounds Surged as Coronavirus Advanced. Now the Game Is Retreating.
item.description: Drawn by open-air acreage, free time and new social distancing guidelines, recreational golfers in the U.S. were playing in droves this month. Then courses started shuttering.
item.dc:creator: Bill Pennington
item.media:credit: Michael Hanson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Playing a round at Indian Creek Golf Course on Saturday.

item.title: Turning Back the Clock on Aging Cells
item.description: Researchers report that they can rejuvenate human cells by reprogramming them to a youthful state.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Wade
item.media:description: A scanning electron micrograph of a human embryonic stem cell.

item.title: Why Mundane Moments Truly Matter
item.description: “How we spend our days is how we spend our lives.”
item.dc:creator: Simran Sethi
item.media:description: An entry from Lissa Jensen’s journal, written sitting at a table late one evening.

item.title: How to Stay Sane When the World Seems Crazy
item.description: Stop and take a breath. The world will keep spinning.
item.dc:creator: Allie Volpe

item.title: 9 Delightful Articles to Help You Get Through This Week
item.description: We’re all just trying to do our best now. These articles might help a little.
item.dc:creator: Tim Herrera

item.title: Burnout Isn’t Just in Your Head. It’s in Your Circumstances.
item.description: We can fight emotional exhaustion by decreasing demands, increasing support and enhancing control.
item.dc:creator: Adam Grant

item.title: A Boston E.R. Doctor's Poem About the Coronavirus
item.description: A Boston emergency room doctor’s battle of words with the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Karen Weise

item.title: Review: ‘One Day at a Time’ Still Standing and Being Counted
item.description: The former Netflix sitcom about a Cuban-American family returns on Pop TV, slightly shorter but big on laughs and purpose.
item.dc:creator: James Poniewozik
item.category: One Day at a Time (TV Program)
item.media:description: The Alvarez family is back after a brush with cancellation, but the move from Netflix to cable TV hasn’t changed what works about “One Day at a Time.” Isabella Gomez, left, plays Elena, the teenage daughter of Penelope (Justina Machado).

item.title: A D.I.Y. Dance for Your Home, From Yvonne Rainer
item.description: The venerated choreographer invites you to try “Passing and Jostling While Being Confined to a Small Apartment.”
item.dc:creator: Brian Seibert
item.category: Passing and Jostling While Being Confined to a Small Apartment (Dance (Non-Ballet))

item.title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘You Find Yourself Lying Once Again in His Bed’
item.description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.

item.title: Carolina Releases Cam Newton, Completes Housecleaning
item.description: The quarterback, a former league M.V.P., was the most visible remnant of the franchise’s old identity. Facing free agency with an uncertain foot injury, 30-year-old Newton may be a tough sell.
item.dc:creator: Ben Shpigel
item.media:description: Cam Newton, the Panthers’ career leader in passing yards (29,041), passing and rushing touchdowns (182 and 58, respectively) and wins by a quarterback (68), will seek a new team after nine seasons in Carolina.

item.title: What Does Our Body Temperature Say About Our Health?
item.description: Humans seem to have cooled over the past 150 years. What does that mean for us now?
item.dc:creator: Kim Tingley
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

item.title: Thalidomide Use Did Happen Here, These Americans Say
item.description: They believe they were harmed in the thalidomide crisis of the 1950s and 1960s.
item.dc:creator: Katie Thomas
item.media:credit: Audra Melton for The New York Times

item.title: Young Adults Come to Grips With Coronavirus Health Risks
item.description: It can be a serious disease for younger people, and many millennials have chronic physical and mental health conditions.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:credit: Brandon Thibodeaux for The New York Times

item.title: Vampire Bats Know Sharing Blood With Friends Is Good Manners
item.description: After a good blood meal, one bat will share with another, if the other bat is family, or has proved to be a reliable friend.
item.dc:creator: James Gorman
item.media:credit: Ben Lascelles/Nature Picture Library, via Alamy
item.media:description: A tight-knit vampire bat community in a hollow tree in the Chaco region of Argentina.

item.title: Trump Has Given Unusual Leeway to Fauci, but Aides Say He’s Losing His Patience
item.description: The president has become increasingly concerned as Dr. Anthony S. Fauci has grown bolder in correcting his falsehoods about the spread of the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman
item.category: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump knows that Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, the director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, is seen as credible with a large portion of the public and with journalists, officials said.

item.title: Try Tiles
item.description: Our soothing matching game may help you de-stress.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: The Crossword, Vertex and More
item.description: Solve the daily puzzle edited by Will Shortz, or try out other games like the Mini and Letter Boxed.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Try Spelling Bee
item.description: Puzzle throughout the day to see how many words you can find.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
